SEARCH
Package project3

Class MyLinkedList<E>

Object
MyLinkedList<E>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of elements in this list
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterable<E>
public class MyLinkedList<E> extends Object implements Iterable<E>
A generic singly linked list implementation. This list does not allow null elements.

  • Constructor Summary

    Constructors
    Constructor
    Description
    MyLinkedList()
    Constructs an empty list with an initial capacity of ten.

    • shiftDown

      public void shiftDown(E data, int shift)
      Shifts the specified data element down the list by a specified number of positions. If the new position is beyond the end of the list, it wraps to the start of the list. For example, if the list is ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e'] and the data is 'c' with a shift of 2, the list will become ['a', 'b', 'd', 'e', 'c']. Or, if the list is [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] and the data is 3 with a shift of 4, the list will become [2, 3, 4, 5, 1].
      Parameters:
      data - the data element to shift
      shift - the number of positions to shift the element down the list

    • shiftUp

      public void shiftUp(E data, int shift)
      Shifts the specified data element up the list by a specified number of positions. If the new position is beyond the start of the list, it wraps to the end of the list. For example, if the list is ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e'] and the data is 'c' and the shift is 2, the list will become ['c', 'a', 'b', 'd', 'e']. Or, if the list is [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] and the data is 3 and the shift is 4, the list will become [5, 1, 2, 3, 4].
      Parameters:
      data - the data element to shift
      shift - the number of positions to shift the element up the list

    • splitAtIndex

      public MyLinkedList<E> splitAtIndex(int index)
      Splits the list at the specified index and returns a new list containing the elements from the index to the end, [index, size-1]. The original list will contain the elements up to the index [0, index-1]. For example, if the list is ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e'] and the index is 2, the original list will be ['a', 'b'] and the returned list will be ['c', 'd', 'e'].
      Parameters:
      index - the index at which to split the list
      Returns:
      a new list containing the elements from the index to the end
      Throws:
      IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the index is out of bounds, i.e., (index < 0 || index >= size())

    • appendList

      public void appendList(MyLinkedList<E> list)
      Appends another list to the end of this list. For example, if this list is ['a', 'b', 'c'] and the list to append is ['d', 'e'], this list will become ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e'].
      Parameters:
      list - the list to append

    • reverse

      public void reverse()
      Reverses the elements in this list. For example, if the list is ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e'], the reversed list will be ['e', 'd', 'c', 'b', 'a'].

    • extractOddNodes

      public MyLinkedList<E> extractOddNodes()
      Extracts nodes from the list that have odd indices and returns a new list containing these nodes. For example, if the list is ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'a'], the returned list will be ['b', 'd'] and this list will be ['a', 'c', 'a']. The original list will contain the nodes with even indices.
      Returns:
      a new list containing the nodes with odd indices

    • rotateRight

      public void rotateRight(int shift)
      Rotates the list to the right by a specified number of positions. If the shift is greater than the size of the list, it wraps around. For example, if the list is [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] and the shift is 2, the list will become [4, 5, 1, 2, 3]. Or, if the list is ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e'] and the shift is 7, the list will become ['d', 'e', 'a', 'b', 'c'].
      Parameters:
      shift - the number of positions to rotate the list to the right
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the shift is negative

    • rotateLeft

      public void rotateLeft(int shift)
      Rotates the list to the left by a specified number of positions. If the shift is greater than the size of the list, it wraps around. For example, if the list is [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] and the shift is 2, the list will become [3, 4, 5, 1, 2]. Or, if the list is ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e'] and the shift is 7, the list will become ['c', 'd', 'e', 'a', 'b'].
      Parameters:
      shift - the number of positions to rotate the list to the left
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the shift is negative

      Removes all elements from the list.
